14
.

Class
Structure
in
Marxian
Theory[Original
Blog]

In
the
grand
tapestry
of
Marxian
economic
analysis
,
one
cannot
help
but
be
drawn
to
the
intricate
web
of
class
structures
that
Marx
himself
wove
into
his
theories
.


Central
to
the
very
essence
of
his
work
,
class
structure
plays
a
pivotal
role
in
understanding
the
dynamics
of
society
,
power
,
and
inequality
.


While
Karl
Marx
'
s
ideas
were
developed
in
the
19th
century
,
they
remain
as
relevant
today
as
they
were
in
his
time
,
sparking
ongoing
debates
and
discussions
among
scholars
and
thinkers
.


This
section
delves
into
the
core
concept
of
class
structure
in
Marxian
theory
,
offering
insights
from
various
perspectives
and
employing
examples
to
elucidate
these
intricate
concepts
.



1
.


The
Fundamental
Division
-
Bourgeoisie
and
Proletariat
:

At
the
heart
of
Marx
'
s
class
structure
lies
the
binary
division
of
society
into
two
primary
classes
:
the
bourgeoisie
and
the
proletariat
.


The
bourgeoisie
,
often
referred
to
as
the
capitalist
class
,
own
the
means
of
production
and
wield
economic
power
.


In
contrast
,
the
proletariat
consists
of
the
laborers
and
workers
who
,
lacking
the
means
of
production
,
must
sell
their
labor
to
survive
.


This
dichotomy
encapsulates
the
core
tension
of
Marxian
theory
,
the
struggle
between
those
who
control
capital
and
those
who
provide
the
labor
.



2
.


The
Role
of
the
Bourgeoisie
:

The
bourgeoisie
'
s
control
over
the
means
of
production
gives
them
immense
influence
not
only
in
the
economic
realm
but
also
in
the
political
and
social
spheres
.


They
determine
the
allocation
of
resources
,
set
the
agenda
,
and
frame
societal
structures
to
maintain
their
dominance
.


A
classic
example
is
the
industrial
revolution
,
which
saw
the
bourgeoisie
amassing
vast
wealth
while
the
working
class
endured
harsh
working
conditions
and
minimal
wages
.



3
.


The
Struggles
of
the
Proletariat
:

For
the
proletariat
,
life
under
capitalism
is
marked
by
insecurity
,
exploitation
,
and
alienation
.


They
work
long
hours
for
minimal
pay
,
often
unable
to
break
free
from
the
cycle
of
poverty
.


Their
plight
is
exemplified
by
historical
events
like
the
labor
strikes
of
the
late
19th
and
early
20th
centuries
,
where
workers
fought
for
better
wages
,
shorter
working
hours
,
and
improved
working
conditions
.



4
.


Class
Consciousness
:

One
of
Marx
'
s
key
ideas
is
the
development
of
class
consciousness
among
the
proletariat
.


It
refers
to
the
realization
of
their
shared
interests
and
the
understanding
that
their
oppression
is
a
result
of
the
capitalist
system
.


An
illustrative
example
is
the
rise
of
labor
unions
and
socialist
movements
,
where
workers
joined
forces
to
demand
their
rights
and
challenge
the
bourgeoisie
'
s
supremacy
.



5
.


The
Middle
Class
-
A
Complex
Entity
:

While
Marx
'
s
theory
primarily
focuses
on
the
bourgeoisie
and
proletariat
,
the
emergence
of
the
middle
class
complicates
this
binary
view
.


The
middle
class
,
including
small
business
owners
and
professionals
,
often
find
themselves
in
a
gray
area
,
as
they
may
experience
aspects
of
both
exploitation
and
privilege
.


This
complexity
has
spurred
debates
on
their
role
within
the
class
structure
.



6
.


Contemporary
Relevance
:

Marx
'
s
analysis
of
class
structure
remains
influential
today
.


The
modern
gig
economy
,
with
its
precarious
work
arrangements
,
reflects
the
ongoing
struggle
of
the
proletariat
.


Additionally
,
discussions
around
income
inequality
and
the
concentration
of
wealth
in
the
hands
of
a
few
resonate
with
Marx
'
s
concerns
about
the
bourgeoisie
'
s
power
.



7
.


Critiques
and
Evolutions
:

It
'
s
essential
to
acknowledge
that
Marx
'
s
class
structure
model
has
faced
critiques
and
adaptations
over
time
.


Some
argue
that
factors
like
race
,
gender
,
and
identity
should
be
incorporated
into
a
more
comprehensive
class
analysis
.


Others
contend
that
the
collapse
of
traditional
class
divisions
in
advanced
capitalist
societies
requires
a
reevaluation
of
Marx
'
s
theory
.



8
.


Conclusion
:

The
concept
of
class
structure
in
Marxian
theory
serves
as
the
backbone
of
his
economic
analysis
,
illuminating
the
power
dynamics
and
social
hierarchies
inherent
in
capitalist
societies
.


By
examining
the
roles
of
the
bourgeoisie
and
proletariat
,
understanding
class
consciousness
,
and
recognizing
the
evolving
nature
of
class
divisions
,
we
can
better
grasp
the
ongoing
relevance
and
complexity
of
Marx
'
s
ideas
in
today
'
s
world
.



-

-

-

-

-


Class
Structure
in
Marxian
Theory
-
Class
struggle
:
The
Backbone
of
Marxian
Economic
Analysis

------------------------------------------------------------------------

15
.

Class
Struggle
and
the
Role
of
the
Proletariat[Original
Blog]

Class
Struggle

Class
struggle
and
the
role
of
the
proletariat
are
central
concepts
in
Marxian
economics
,
reflecting
the
radical
roots
of
heterodoxy
.


These
ideas
revolve
around
the
belief
that
society
is
divided
into
two
main
classes
,
the
bourgeoisie
(the
capitalist
class)
and
the
proletariat
(the
working
class)
,
and
that
the
inherent
conflict
between
them
drives
historical
and
social
change
.


The
bourgeoisie
,
who
own
the
means
of
production
,
seek
to
maximize
their
profits
by
exploiting
the
labor
of
the
proletariat
,
who
have
no
choice
but
to
sell
their
labor
power
to
survive
.


This
unequal
power
dynamic
creates
a
perpetual
struggle
between
the
two
classes
,
as
the
bourgeoisie
aim
to
maintain
their
dominance
while
the
proletariat
strive
for
better
working
conditions
,
higher
wages
,
and
ultimately
,
the
overthrow
of
the
capitalist
system
.



1
.


Historical
Materialism
:
Marxists
argue
that
the
class
struggle
is
not
a
mere
ideological
or
political
conflict
,
but
a
material
one
rooted
in
the
economic
relations
of
production
.


Marx
developed
the
concept
of
historical
materialism
to
understand
how
different
modes
of
production
throughout
history
have
shaped
the
class
struggle
.


For
instance
,
in
feudal
societies
,
the
conflict
was
between
the
feudal
lords
and
the
serfs
,
while
in
capitalist
societies
,
it
is
between
the
bourgeoisie
and
the
proletariat
.


Historical
materialism
provides
a
framework
for
analyzing
the
dynamics
of
class
struggle
across
different
historical
periods
and
societies
.



2
.


Exploitation
of
Labor
:
The
capitalist
mode
of
production
relies
on
the
extraction
of
surplus
value
from
the
labor
of
the
proletariat
.


Capitalists
pay
workers
a
wage
that
is
less
than
the
value
they
produce
,
resulting
in
the
exploitation
of
their
labor
.


This
surplus
value
is
then
accumulated
as
profit
by
the
bourgeoisie
.


The
perpetual
need
to
accumulate
capital
drives
capitalists
to
constantly
increase
the
intensity
and
duration
of
labor
,
leading
to
worsening
working
conditions
and
alienation
for
the
proletariat
.



3
.


Alienation
:
Marx
argued
that
under
capitalism
,
the
proletariat
becomes
alienated
from
their
labor
,
themselves
,
and
their
fellow
workers
.


Due
to
the
division
of
labor
and
the
commodification
of
labor
power
,
workers
are
reduced
to
mere
cogs
in
the
capitalist
machine
,
where
their
work
becomes
a
means
of
survival
rather
than
a
source
of
fulfillment
.


This
alienation
from
the
product
of
their
labor
and
the
process
itself
creates
a
sense
of
powerlessness
and
disconnect
,
further
fueling
the
class
struggle
.



4
.


Class
Consciousness
:
Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
,
through
their
shared
experiences
of
exploitation
and
alienation
,
would
develop
class
consciousness
–
an
understanding
of
their
collective
interests
and
the
need
for
revolutionary
action
.


Class
consciousness
enables
the
proletariat
to
recognize
their
role
as
a
revolutionary
class
and
to
unite
in
their
struggle
against
the
bourgeoisie
.


It
is
through
class
consciousness
that
the
proletariat
can
challenge
the
dominant
ideology
perpetuated
by
the
ruling
class
and
envision
an
alternative
society
based
on
socialist
principles
.



5
.


Role
of
the
Proletariat
:
The
proletariat
,
as
the
largest
and
most
exploited
class
in
capitalist
societies
,
plays
a
crucial
role
in
the
class
struggle
.


Marx
argued
that
the
proletariat
,
once
conscious
of
their
collective
power
,
would
rise
up
against
the
bourgeoisie
,
overthrow
capitalism
,
and
establish
a
classless
society
.


This
revolutionary
role
of
the
proletariat
is
seen
as
a
historical
necessity
,
driven
by
the
contradictions
and
inherent
instability
of
the
capitalist
system
.



6
.


Revolutionary
Potential
:
The
revolutionary
potential
of
the
proletariat
is
often
debated
among
Marxists
.


Some
argue
that
the
increasing
precarity
and
exploitation
faced
by
the
working
class
in
contemporary
capitalism
will
inevitably
lead
to
a
revolutionary
uprising
.


Others
contend
that
the
fragmentation
and
diversification
of
the
working
class
,
along
with
the
co-optation
of
certain
segments
through
higher
wages
and
benefits
,
may
hinder
the
development
of
a
unified
revolutionary
force
.


Nevertheless
,
the
role
of
the
proletariat
in
challenging
the
capitalist
system
remains
a
central
tenet
of
Marxian
economics
.



The
concept
of
class
struggle
and
the
role
of
the
proletariat
are
fundamental
to
understanding
Marxian
economics
.


The
perpetual
conflict
between
the
bourgeoisie
and
the
proletariat
,
driven
by
exploitation
and
alienation
,
forms
the
basis
for
social
change
and
the
potential
for
revolutionary
transformation
.


While
the
revolutionary
potential
of
the
proletariat
may
be
subject
to
debate
,
the
analysis
of
class
struggle
provides
a
critical
lens
through
which
to
examine
the
dynamics
of
power
and
inequality
in
capitalist
societies
.



-

-

-

-

-


Class
Struggle
and
the
Role
of
the
Proletariat
-
Marxian
Economics
:
Exploring
the
Radical
Roots
of
Heterodoxy

------------------------------------------------------------------------

16
.

The
Concept
of
the
Bourgeoisie[Original
Blog]

The
Concept
of
the
Bourgeoisie
is
a
central
element
of
Marxian
economics
,
and
it
plays
a
pivotal
role
in
understanding
class
struggle
and
the
dynamics
of
capitalist
societies
.


The
term
"bourgeoisie"
refers
to
the
capitalist
class
or
the
owners
of
the
means
of
production
,
such
as
factories
,
businesses
,
and
land
.


This
class
is
distinct
from
the
working
class
,
known
as
the
proletariat
,
who
sell
their
labor
to
the
bourgeoisie
in
exchange
for
wages
.


The
concept
of
the
bourgeoisie
is
multifaceted
and
has
been
analyzed
from
various
perspectives
,
providing
a
nuanced
understanding
of
its
role
in
society
.



1
.


Historical
Evolution
of
the
Bourgeoisie
:

The
concept
of
the
bourgeoisie
has
a
historical
context
.


It
emerged
as
a
distinct
class
during
the
transition
from
feudalism
to
capitalism
.


In
the
18th
and
19th
centuries
,
with
the
rise
of
industrialization
,
the
bourgeoisie
gained
economic
power
and
influence
.


They
were
instrumental
in
shaping
the
modern
capitalist
system
,
which
shifted
the
balance
of
power
from
the
aristocracy
to
the
capitalist
class
.


An
example
of
this
can
be
seen
in
the
Industrial
Revolution
,
where
the
bourgeoisie
invested
in
new
technologies
and
industries
,
leading
to
significant
societal
changes
.



2
.


Economic
Exploitation
:

Marxian
economics
argues
that
the
bourgeoisie
maintains
its
power
through
the
exploitation
of
the
proletariat
.


The
bourgeoisie
profits
by
paying
workers
less
than
the
value
of
their
labor
,
resulting
in
surplus
value
.


This
surplus
value
is
a
fundamental
source
of
wealth
for
the
bourgeoisie
,
as
they
accumulate
capital
by
extracting
it
from
the
working
class
.


This
economic
relationship
is
exemplified
by
the
wage
labor
system
,
where
workers
produce
goods
or
services
for
their
employers
in
exchange
for
a
wage
,
while
the
bourgeoisie
reaps
the
profits
.



3
.


Class
Consciousness
:

Understanding
the
bourgeoisie
also
involves
the
concept
of
"class
consciousness
.

"
Marx
argued
that
the
bourgeoisie
had
a
clear
understanding
of
their
class
interests
and
sought
to
protect
and
expand
their
economic
power
.


This
consciousness
led
to
the
development
of
institutions
,
such
as
corporations
and
financial
markets
,
that
furthered
their
interests
.


The
bourgeoisie
'
s
ability
to
shape
economic
policies
in
their
favor
highlights
the
influence
of
class
consciousness
in
maintaining
their
position
.



4
.


Contradictions
and
Crises
:

An
important
aspect
of
the
bourgeoisie
is
its
role
in
creating
contradictions
within
the
capitalist
system
.


Marx
posited
that
capitalism
inherently
contains
contradictions
and
crises
due
to
the
pursuit
of
profit
and
competition
among
capitalists
.


These
crises
,
such
as
economic
recessions
and
financial
instability
,
can
have
widespread
consequences
for
society
.


The
2008
financial
crisis
serves
as
a
modern
example
of
how
the
actions
and
decisions
of
the
bourgeoisie
can
lead
to
systemic
crises
.



5
.


Global
Bourgeoisie
:

The
concept
of
the
bourgeoisie
extends
beyond
national
borders
.


In
a
globalized
world
,
the
bourgeoisie
is
not
limited
to
one
country
but
forms
a
transnational
elite
.


They
benefit
from
the
global
movement
of
capital
and
resources
,
often
at
the
expense
of
workers
in
less
developed
countries
.


Multinational
corporations
and
international
financial
institutions
are
powerful
entities
representing
the
interests
of
the
global
bourgeoisie
.


This
globalization
of
capitalism
has
led
to
debates
about
inequality
on
a
global
scale
.



6
.


Challenges
to
the
Bourgeoisie
:

While
the
bourgeoisie
has
maintained
its
power
for
centuries
,
it
is
not
without
challenges
.


Movements
advocating
for
workers
'

rights
,
wealth
redistribution
,
and
social
justice
have
questioned
the
concentration
of
power
and
wealth
in
the
hands
of
the
bourgeoisie
.


Examples
include
labor
unions
,
socialist
movements
,
and
policies
aimed
at
regulating
markets
and
reducing
income
inequality
.



The
concept
of
the
bourgeoisie
is
a
complex
and
multifaceted
one
,
central
to
the
understanding
of
capitalist
societies
.


Its
historical
evolution
,
economic
exploitation
,
class
consciousness
,
role
in
crises
,
global
reach
,
and
the
challenges
it
faces
all
contribute
to
a
rich
analysis
of
this
key
element
of
Marxian
economics
.


This
understanding
serves
as
a
foundation
for
examining
the
dynamics
of
class
struggle
and
the
ongoing
debates
about
economic
and
social
justice
in
contemporary
society
.



-

-

-

-

-


The
Concept
of
the
Bourgeoisie
-
Bourgeoisie
:
Beyond
the
Bourgeoisie
:
Examining
Marxian
Economics

------------------------------------------------------------------------

17
.

Challenges
and
Pitfalls
in
Social
Class
Segmentation[Original
Blog]

1
.


Subjectivity
and
Fluidity
:

-
Social
class
is
not
a
fixed
attribute
;
it
'
s
fluid
and
context-dependent
.


People
can
move
up
or
down
the
social
ladder
due
to
changes
in
income
,
education
,
or
lifestyle
.


For
instance
,
an
entrepreneur
who
experiences
financial
setbacks
might
temporarily
shift
from
an
upper-middle-class
position
to
a
lower
one
.



-
Example
:
Consider
a
freelance
artist
who
earns
a
modest
income
but
identifies
with
the
cultural
tastes
and
preferences
of
the
upper
class
.


Their
social
class
might
be
ambiguous
,
as
it
doesn
'
t
neatly
fit
into
predefined
categories
.



2
.


Multiple
Dimensions
of
Class
:

-
Social
class
isn
'
t
solely
about
income
or
occupation
.


It
encompasses
education
,
cultural
capital
,
and
consumption
patterns
.


Researchers
often
use
a
combination
of
these
factors
to
create
more
nuanced
class
segments
.



-
Example
:
A
highly
educated
professor
might
have
a
lower
income
than
a
successful
business
owner
,
yet
their
cultural
capital
and
social
connections
place
them
in
a
different
class
stratum
.



3
.


Cultural
Bias
and
Stereotypes
:

-
Class
segmentation
can
perpetuate
stereotypes
.


For
instance
,
assuming
that
all
blue-collar
workers
lack
sophistication
or
that
all
wealthy
individuals
are
cultured
.



-
Example
:
Labeling
someone
as
"working
class"
based
on
their
occupation
without
considering
their
interests
,
education
,
or
aspirations
can
lead
to
misclassification
.



4
.


Sampling
Challenges
:

-
Obtaining
representative
samples
for
class
segmentation
surveys
is
difficult
.


People
might
not
accurately
report
their
income
or
social
status
due
to
privacy
concerns
or
social
desirability
bias
.



-
Example
:
A
survey
targeting
high-income
professionals
might
inadvertently
exclude
those
who
prefer
not
to
disclose
their
wealth
.



5
.


Regional
Variation
:

-
Social
class
norms
vary
across
regions
and
cultures
.


What
signifies
affluence
in
one
country
might
not
hold
true
elsewhere
.



-
Example
:
Owning
a
large
suburban
house
with
a
white
picket
fence
might
symbolize
middle-class
stability
in
the
United
States
,
but
it
could
be
irrelevant
in
densely
populated
urban
areas
of
Asia
.



6
.


Intersectionality
:

-
Social
class
intersects
with
other
identity
markers
such
as
race
,
gender
,
and
ethnicity
.


These
intersections
influence
experiences
and
opportunities
.



-
Example
:
A
working-class
woman
of
color
faces
different
challenges
than
a
white
man
from
the
same
economic
background
.


Intersectional
analysis
is
crucial
for
accurate
segmentation
.



7
.


Temporal
Changes
:

-
Social
class
dynamics
evolve
over
time
.


Economic
recessions
,
technological
advancements
,
and
cultural
shifts
impact
class
boundaries
.



-
Example
:
The
rise
of
the
gig
economy
has
blurred
traditional
class
lines
,
with
freelancers
and
contract
workers
challenging
conventional
definitions
.



8
.


Ethical
Considerations
:

-
Segmentation
can
reinforce
inequality
if
used
to
exclude
or
discriminate
.


Ethical
guidelines
are
essential
to
prevent
harm
.



-
Example
:
A
luxury
brand
targeting
only
the
upper
class
might
inadvertently
alienate
potential
customers
who
aspire
to
own
their
products
.



In
summary
,
social
class
segmentation
is
a
delicate
balancing
act
.


Researchers
and
marketers
must
navigate
these
challenges
while
recognizing
the
nuances
and
complexities
inherent
in
class
consciousness
.


Remember
that
behind
every
data
point
lies
a
human
experience
shaped
by
culture
,
history
,
and
individual
aspirations
.



-

-

-

-

-


Challenges
and
Pitfalls
in
Social
Class
Segmentation
-
Segmentation
by
social
class
:
How
to
Segment
Your
Audience
by
Their
Social
Status
and
Class
Consciousness

------------------------------------------------------------------------

18
.

An
Analysis
of
Marxs
Critique[Original
Blog]

Class
struggle
and
capitalism
are
two
concepts
that
have
been
the
subject
of
much
analysis
and
critique
in
the
field
of
Marxism
.


Karl
Marx
,
one
of
the
most
influential
philosophers
and
economists
of
the
19th
century
,
believed
that
capitalism
inevitably
leads
to
class
struggle
and
that
this
struggle
would
ultimately
result
in
the
overthrow
of
the
ruling
class
by
the
working
class
.


This
analysis
has
been
the
foundation
of
Marxist
thought
and
has
been
the
subject
of
much
debate
and
discussion
among
scholars
and
theorists
.



1
.


Marx
believed
that
capitalism
creates
a
class
system
where
the
bourgeoisie
,
or
the
capitalist
class
,
owns
the
means
of
production
and
exploits
the
working
class
,
or
the
proletariat
,
for
their
labor
.


The
working
class
is
paid
wages
that
are
not
equivalent
to
the
value
of
the
goods
and
services
they
produce
,
while
the
bourgeoisie
accumulate
wealth
and
maintain
their
power
through
the
control
of
the
means
of
production
.



2
.


This
class
struggle
,
according
to
Marx
,
is
the
driving
force
behind
historical
change
.


He
believed
that
as
the
working
class
becomes
more
conscious
of
their
exploitation
and
the
injustices
of
the
capitalist
system
,
they
will
eventually
rise
up
and
overthrow
the
ruling
class
.


This
would
lead
to
the
establishment
of
a
socialist
system
,
where
the
means
of
production
are
owned
and
controlled
by
the
workers
themselves
.



3
.


However
,
there
are
criticisms
of
Marx
'
s
analysis
of
class
struggle
and
capitalism
.


Some
argue
that
his
theory
is
too
simplistic
and
fails
to
take
into
account
the
complexities
of
modern
capitalist
societies
.


Others
argue
that
his
theory
is
too
deterministic
and
ignores
the
agency
of
individuals
and
their
ability
to
effect
change
within
the
system
.



4
.


Despite
these
criticisms
,
Marx
'
s
analysis
of
class
struggle
and
capitalism
remains
a
critical
component
of
Marxist
thought
and
has
influenced
the
development
of
socialist
and
communist
movements
around
the
world
.


The
ideas
of
class
consciousness
,
exploitation
,
and
the
struggle
for
economic
and
social
justice
continue
to
be
relevant
and
important
today
.



Overall
,
Marx
'
s
critique
of
capitalism
and
class
struggle
provides
a
unique
perspective
on
the
social
and
economic
forces
that
shape
our
world
.


By
understanding
the
dynamics
of
class
struggle
and
the
exploitative
nature
of
capitalism
,
we
can
better
understand
the
inequalities
and
injustices
that
exist
within
our
society
and
work
towards
creating
a
more
just
and
equitable
world
.



-

-

-

-

-


An
Analysis
of
Marxs
Critique
-
Marxism
:
Exploring
Marxism
:
The
Legacy
of
Karl
Marx

------------------------------------------------------------------------

19
.

The
Role
of
the
Proletariat
in
the
Marxist
Framework[Original
Blog]

The
idea
of
the
proletariat
being
the
revolutionary
class
is
a
fundamental
tenet
of
Marxism
.


Proletariat
refers
to
the
working
class
,
and
according
to
Marx
'
s
theory
,
they
are
the
ones
who
are
oppressed
by
the
bourgeoisie
,
the
ruling
class
.


The
proletariat
is
central
to
the
Marxist
framework
because
it
is
this
class
that
Marx
believed
would
bring
about
the
revolution
that
would
overthrow
the
capitalist
system
.



From
a
Marxist
perspective
,
the
proletariat
'
s
role
in
the
revolution
is
based
on
the
fact
that
they
are
the
most
exploited
class
in
society
.


They
are
the
ones
who
do
most
of
the
work
but
receive
the
least
amount
of
compensation
.


This
exploitation
is
what
motivates
the
proletarians
to
rise
up
and
demand
a
fairer
system
.


Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
'
s
revolutionary
potential
comes
from
their
collective
action
,
which
is
why
he
believed
that
the
class
struggle
was
a
crucial
part
of
history
.



To
understand
the
role
of
the
proletariat
in
the
Marxist
framework
,
below
are
some
in-depth
points
that
provide
more
information
on
the
subject
:

1
.


The
Proletariat
is
the
Revolutionary
Class
:
According
to
Marx
,
the
proletariat
is
the
revolutionary
class
because
they
have
nothing
to
lose
but
their
chains
.


They
are
the
ones
who
are
most
vulnerable
to
exploitation
,
and
they
have
the
most
to
gain
from
a
revolution
.


Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
'
s
revolutionary
potential
came
from
their
collective
action
,
which
is
why
he
believed
that
the
class
struggle
was
a
crucial
part
of
history
.



2
.


Economic
Determinism
:
Marx
believed
that
the
economic
system
was
the
driving
force
behind
history
.


He
argued
that
the
capitalist
system
was
inherently
unstable
and
that
it
would
eventually
collapse
under
its
own
weight
.


Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
would
be
the
class
that
would
bring
about
this
collapse
,
as
they
would
be
the
ones
who
would
suffer
the
most
from
the
system
'
s
instability
.



3
.


Class
Consciousness
:
Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
needed
to
become
aware
of
their
exploitation
and
oppression
.


He
believed
that
the
proletariat
'
s
class
consciousness
would
be
the
key
to
their
revolutionary
potential
.


The
more
conscious
the
proletariat
became
of
their
situation
,
the
more
likely
they
were
to
rise
up
and
demand
change
.



4
.


Revolutionary
Action
:
Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
'
s
revolutionary
potential
would
be
realized
through
their
collective
action
.


He
argued
that
the
proletariat
needed
to
organize
themselves
into
a
political
force
that
could
challenge
the
bourgeoisie
'
s
power
.


Marx
believed
that
the
proletarian
revolution
would
be
a
violent
one
,
and
that
it
would
be
necessary
to
overthrow
the
existing
order
to
create
a
fairer
system
.



The
role
of
the
proletariat
in
the
Marxist
framework
is
central
to
understanding
Marxism
as
a
whole
.


Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
was
the
revolutionary
class
that
would
bring
about
the
downfall
of
the
capitalist
system
.


The
proletariat
'
s
role
in
the
revolution
is
based
on
their
collective
action
,
economic
determinism
,
class
consciousness
,
and
revolutionary
action
.


The
ultimate
goal
of
the
proletarian
revolution
is
to
create
a
more
equitable
society
that
is
free
from
exploitation
and
oppression
.



-

-

-

-

-


The
Role
of
the
Proletariat
in
the
Marxist
Framework
-
Proletarian
revolution
:
Karl
Marx
'
s
Hope
for
Liberation

------------------------------------------------------------------------

20
.

The
Role
of
the
Proletariat
in
the
Revolution[Original
Blog]

The
working
class
,
or
the
proletariat
,
plays
a
crucial
role
in
Karl
Marx
'
s
call
for
radical
change
.


According
to
Marx
,
the
proletariat
represents
the
majority
of
the
population
who
are
exploited
by
the
capitalist
class
,
or
the
bourgeoisie
.


The
proletariat
'
s
exploitation
is
a
result
of
the
capitalist
system
,
which
prioritizes
profit
over
the
well-being
of
workers
.


Marx
believed
that
it
is
the
proletariat
'
s
duty
to
overthrow
the
bourgeoisie
and
establish
a
socialist
society
where
the
means
of
production
are
collectively
owned
and
controlled
by
the
working
class
.



From
a
Marxist
perspective
,
the
role
of
the
proletariat
in
the
revolution
can
be
summarized
in
the
following
points
:

1
.


The
proletariat
is
the
revolutionary
class
:
Marx
argued
that
the
proletariat
has
the
potential
to
overthrow
the
capitalist
system
because
they
are
the
most
exploited
and
oppressed
class
.


The
proletariat
'
s
revolutionary
potential
comes
from
their
position
in
the
capitalist
economy
as
wage
laborers
who
have
nothing
to
lose
but
their
chains
.



2
.


The
proletariat
must
organize
:
Marx
believed
that
the
proletariat
must
organize
themselves
into
a
class-conscious
movement
to
achieve
their
revolutionary
goals
.


This
means
that
the
working
class
must
recognize
their
shared
interests
and
unite
to
overthrow
the
capitalist
class
.



3
.


The
proletariat
must
seize
the
means
of
production
:
Once
the
working
class
has
organized
and
gained
class
consciousness
,
they
must
seize
control
of
the
means
of
production
from
the
bourgeoisie
.


This
means
that
factories
,
land
,
and
other
resources
must
be
collectively
owned
and
controlled
by
the
working
class
.



4
.


The
proletariat
must
establish
a
socialist
society
:
Marx
believed
that
the
ultimate
goal
of
the
revolution
is
to
establish
a
socialist
society
where
the
means
of
production
are
owned
and
controlled
by
the
working
class
.


In
a
socialist
society
,
the
well-being
of
all
members
of
society
is
prioritized
over
profit
.



One
example
of
the
proletariat
'
s
revolutionary
potential
can
be
seen
in
the
Russian
Revolution
of
1917
.


The
Bolsheviks
,
a
socialist
party
led
by
Vladimir
Lenin
,
gained
support
from
the
working
class
and
successfully
overthrew
the
capitalist
government
.


The
Bolsheviks
established
a
socialist
government
and
implemented
policies
that
prioritized
the
well-being
of
workers
,
such
as
a
minimum
wage
and
eight-hour
workday
.



The
proletariat
plays
a
central
role
in
Karl
Marx
'
s
call
for
radical
change
.


The
working
class
'
s
revolutionary
potential
comes
from
their
position
in
the
capitalist
economy
as
the
most
exploited
and
oppressed
class
.


The
proletariat
must
organize
,
seize
the
means
of
production
,
and
establish
a
socialist
society
to
achieve
their
revolutionary
goals
.


The
Russian
Revolution
of
1917
serves
as
an
example
of
the
proletariat
'
s
revolutionary
potential
and
the
successful
establishment
of
a
socialist
government
.



-

-

-

-

-


The
Role
of
the
Proletariat
in
the
Revolution
-
Revolution
:
Revolutionizing
Society
:
Karl
Marx
'
s
Call
for
Radical
Change

------------------------------------------------------------------------

21
.

Engels
Definition
and
Characteristics
of
the
Proletariat[Original
Blog]

The
concept
of
the
proletariat
is
one
of
the
most
essential
elements
of
Marxist
theory
.


Friedrich
Engels
,
who
co-authored
The
Communist
Manifesto
with
Karl
Marx
,
provided
a
definition
and
characteristics
of
the
proletariat
in
his
work
,
The
Condition
of
the
Working
Class
in
England
.


Engels
considered
the
proletariat
as
a
social
class
consisting
of
individuals
who
sell
their
labor
power
to
capitalists
in
exchange
for
wages
.


He
believed
that
the
proletariat
'
s
position
in
society
is
one
of
exploitation
,
with
capitalists
using
their
labor
to
generate
profits
.



Engels
'

definition
of
the
proletariat
also
included
specific
characteristics
that
he
believed
identified
them
as
a
distinct
social
class
.


These
characteristics
include
:

1
.


Lack
of
control
over
the
means
of
production
:
Engels
argued
that
the
proletariat
had
no
ownership
or
control
over
the
tools
,
machinery
,
and
resources
they
used
to
produce
goods
and
services
.


This
lack
of
control
made
them
dependent
on
capitalists
for
employment
and
wages
.



2
.


Proletarianization
:
Engels
believed
that
the
process
of
industrialization
transformed
peasants
,
artisans
,
and
small
business
owners
into
the
proletariat
.


This
process
involved
the
displacement
of
workers
from
their
traditional
means
of
livelihood
and
forcing
them
to
sell
their
labor
to
capitalists
.



3
.


Consciousness
of
their
class
position
:
Engels
argued
that
the
proletariat
was
becoming
increasingly
aware
of
their
class
position
and
their
exploitation
by
capitalists
.


This
awareness
would
eventually
lead
to
class
consciousness
,
where
workers
would
unite
and
seize
control
of
the
means
of
production
.



4
.


Internationalism
:
Engels
believed
that
the
proletariat
was
a
global
class
,
with
workers
in
different
countries
sharing
a
common
interest
in
overthrowing
capitalism
.


This
internationalism
would
lead
to
the
formation
of
a
global
workers
'

revolution
.



Overall
,
Engels
'

definition
and
characteristics
of
the
proletariat
highlight
the
exploitation
and
struggle
of
the
working
class
under
capitalism
.


These
ideas
have
been
influential
in
Marxist
theory
and
have
shaped
the
understanding
of
social
class
and
class
struggle
.


For
example
,
the
labor
strikes
and
protests
organized
by
workers
in
the
late
19th
and
early
20th
centuries
were
aimed
at
improving
their
working
conditions
and
wages
,
which
were
often
inadequate
under
capitalist
systems
.



-

-

-

-

-


Engels
Definition
and
Characteristics
of
the
Proletariat
-
Proletariat
:
Friedrich
Engels
:
Concept
of
the
Working
Class

------------------------------------------------------------------------

22
.

Economic
Determinism
and
Social
Change[Original
Blog]

economic
determinism
is
a
key
concept
in
Marxian
economic
thought
that
explores
the
relationship
between
the
economy
and
social
change
.


According
to
this
perspective
,
the
economic
structure
of
society
is
the
primary
driver
of
social
development
,
shaping
the
beliefs
,
values
,
and
institutions
that
exist
within
a
given
society
.


This
concept
,
rooted
in
historical
materialism
,
provides
a
framework
for
understanding
how
economic
factors
influence
the
course
of
history
and
shape
the
dynamics
of
social
transformation
.



From
a
Marxian
perspective
,
economic
determinism
argues
that
the
mode
of
production
,
or
the
way
in
which
goods
are
produced
and
distributed
,
forms
the
foundation
of
social
life
.


The
economic
structure
of
society
,
comprising
the
relations
of
production
and
the
forces
of
production
,
determines
the
social
relations
and
hierarchies
that
exist
within
it
.


This
means
that
the
dominant
economic
class
,
which
controls
the
means
of
production
,
also
wields
significant
power
and
influence
over
the
political
,
cultural
,
and
ideological
aspects
of
society
.



1
.


Economic
Determinism
and
Class
Struggle
:
One
of
the
central
tenets
of
economic
determinism
is
the
idea
that
social
change
is
driven
by
class
struggle
.


Marx
argued
that
throughout
history
,
societies
have
been
characterized
by
a
series
of
class
antagonisms
,
pitting
the
ruling
class
against
the
working
class
.


These
conflicts
arise
due
to
the
inherent
contradictions
within
the
capitalist
mode
of
production
,
where
the
pursuit
of
profit
by
the
bourgeoisie
leads
to
the
exploitation
of
the
proletariat
.


As
the
working
class
becomes
increasingly
aware
of
their
exploitation
,
they
engage
in
collective
action
and
struggle
against
the
ruling
class
,
ultimately
leading
to
social
change
.



2
.


Economic
Determinism
and
Technological
Advancement
:
Another
aspect
of
economic
determinism
is
the
role
of
technological
advancement
in
shaping
social
change
.


Marx
believed
that
technological
progress
,
driven
by
the
need
for
increased
efficiency
and
productivity
,
creates
the
conditions
for
social
transformation
.


For
example
,
the
Industrial
Revolution
in
the
18th
and
19th
centuries
brought
about
significant
changes
in
the
economic
structure
of
society
,
leading
to
the
rise
of
capitalism
and
the
emergence
of
a
new
working
class
.


Technological
advancements
such
as
the
steam
engine
and
mechanized
production
methods
fundamentally
altered
the
mode
of
production
,
resulting
in
profound
social
and
economic
changes
.



3
.


Economic
Determinism
and
Ideology
:
Economic
determinism
also
emphasizes
the
influence
of
ideology
in
maintaining
and
reproducing
the
existing
economic
structure
.


Marx
argued
that
the
ruling
class
,
through
their
control
of
key
institutions
such
as
the
media
,
education
,
and
the
state
,
propagates
a
dominant
ideology
that
justifies
and
legitimizes
the
existing
social
order
.


This
ideology
,
often
referred
to
as
false
consciousness
,
serves
to
maintain
the
status
quo
and
prevent
the
working
class
from
recognizing
their
exploitation
and
engaging
in
collective
action
.


However
,
Marx
believed
that
through
class
struggle
and
the
development
of
class
consciousness
,
the
working
class
can
overcome
this
false
consciousness
and
challenge
the
dominant
ideology
,
paving
the
way
for
social
change
.



In
summary
,
economic
determinism
is
a
fundamental
concept
in
Marxian
economic
thought
that
highlights
the
interplay
between
the
economy
and
social
change
.


It
asserts
that
the
economic
structure
of
society
,
including
the
mode
of
production
and
class
relations
,
serves
as
the
primary
driver
of
historical
development
.


By
understanding
the
role
of
economic
factors
in
shaping
society
,
we
can
gain
insights
into
the
dynamics
of
social
transformation
and
the
potential
for
creating
a
more
equitable
and
just
society
.



-

-

-

-

-


Economic
Determinism
and
Social
Change
-
Historical
materialism
:
Tracing
the
Path
of
Marxian
Economic
Thought

------------------------------------------------------------------------

23
.

The
Proletariat
in
Marxian
Economic
Thought[Original
Blog]

Economic
Thought

In
the
intricate
tapestry
of
Marxian
economic
thought
,
the
concept
of
the
proletariat
stands
as
a
cornerstone
,
representing
a
pivotal
force
that
propels
the
dynamics
of
capitalism
.


The
term
"proletariat"
refers
to
the
working
class
,
individuals
who
,
in
Marxist
terms
,
do
not
own
the
means
of
production
but
sell
their
labor
power
for
wages
.


This
section
delves
into
the
nuanced
dimensions
of
the
proletariat
within
Marxian
economic
analysis
,
examining
the
role
,
challenges
,
and
implications
associated
with
this
critical
social
class
.



Marx
viewed
the
proletariat
as
a
revolutionary
forcea
class
with
nothing
to
lose
but
its
chains
.


From
his
perspective
,
the
inherent
contradictions
within
capitalism
would
propel
the
proletariat
towards
a
historical
mission
:
to
overthrow
the
bourgeoisie
and
establish
a
classless
society
.


Critics
argue
that
this
perspective
oversimplifies
the
dynamics
of
social
change
,
emphasizing
class
struggle
as
the
primary
driver
of
historical
progression
.


However
,
proponents
of
Marxian
thought
assert
that
the
proletariat
'
s
central
position
in
production
endows
them
with
the
potential
to
disrupt
the
capitalist
system
from
within
.



1
.


Exploitation
and
Alienation
:

-
The
proletariat
,
according
to
Marx
,
experiences
exploitation
and
alienation
within
the
capitalist
mode
of
production
.


Their
labor
,
a
commodity
,
is
subjected
to
the
whims
of
the
market
,
resulting
in
surplus
value
appropriated
by
the
bourgeoisie
.


This
process
not
only
leads
to
economic
disparity
but
also
generates
a
sense
of
alienation
as
workers
become
detached
from
the
products
of
their
labor
.



2
.


Class
Consciousness
:

-
Marx
envisioned
the
proletariat
developing
class
consciousnessa
realization
of
their
shared
exploitation
and
collective
interests
.


Achieving
class
consciousness
was
deemed
crucial
for
the
proletariat
to
unite
and
undertake
revolutionary
action
.


Historical
examples
,
such
as
labor
movements
and
strikes
,
serve
as
manifestations
of
this
collective
awareness
among
the
working
class
.



3
.


Global
Proletariat
and
Imperialism
:

-
As
capitalism
expanded
globally
,
so
did
the
concept
of
the
proletariat
.


The
interconnection
of
workers
across
borders
became
evident
,
challenging
traditional
notions
of
a
localized
working
class
.


Imperialism
,
as
an
advanced
stage
of
capitalism
,
accentuates
global
economic
inequalities
,
with
the
proletariat
facing
distinct
challenges
in
different
regions
.



4
.


Technological
Advancements
and
the
Proletariat
:

-
The
impact
of
technological
advancements
on
the
proletariat
is
a
topic
of
contemporary
relevance
.


automation
and
artificial
intelligence
pose
challenges
to
traditional
labor
roles
,
reshaping
the
landscape
of
the
working
class
.


While
some
argue
that
technology
may
liberate
the
proletariat
from
menial
tasks
,
others
express
concerns
about
job
displacement
and
heightened
economic
inequality
.



5
.


Proletariat
in
Non-Industrialized
Settings
:

-
Marx
'
s
analysis
primarily
focused
on
industrialized
societies
,
and
critics
contend
that
his
framework
might
not
fully
capture
the
experiences
of
the
working
class
in
non-industrialized
settings
.


Exploring
how
the
concept
adapts
to
different
economic
structures
provides
a
comprehensive
understanding
of
the
proletariat
'
s
role
in
diverse
contexts
.



In
navigating
the
labyrinth
of
Marxian
economic
thought
,
the
proletariat
emerges
as
a
dynamic
force
,
subject
to
historical
shifts
and
contextual
intricacies
.


By
critically
examining
its
role
within
capitalism
,
one
can
unravel
the
multifaceted
layers
that
characterize
the
relationship
between
the
working
class
and
the
broader
socio-economic
landscape
.



-

-

-

-

-


The
Proletariat
in
Marxian
Economic
Thought
-
Proletariat
:
The
Proletariat
:
Crucial
Actors
in
Marxian
Economic
Analysis

------------------------------------------------------------------------

24
.

Collective
Action
and
the
Path
to
Empowerment[Original
Blog]

Collective
action

In
the
realm
of
Marxian
economics
and
the
pursuit
of
empowering
the
proletariat
,
the
concept
of
collective
action
emerges
as
a
potent
force
for
change
.


It
represents
a
key
mechanism
through
which
individuals
,
often
marginalized
and
disempowered
,
can
unify
their
efforts
to
challenge
established
power
structures
and
advocate
for
their
rights
and
interests
.


At
its
core
,
collective
action
embodies
the
idea
that
when
people
join
together
to
pursue
common
goals
,
they
become
a
force
to
be
reckoned
with
.


This
section
explores
the
significance
of
collective
action
from
various
perspectives
,
shedding
light
on
how
it
can
be
a
transformative
tool
for
achieving
empowerment
in
a
capitalist
society
.



1
.


Solidarity
in
Numbers
:

Collective
action
hinges
on
the
belief
that
there
is
strength
in
numbers
.


The
more
individuals
unite
to
address
shared
concerns
,
the
greater
their
collective
power
becomes
.


An
illustrative
example
of
this
is
labor
unions
.


These
organizations
bring
workers
together
to
negotiate
for
better
wages
,
working
conditions
,
and
benefits
.


When
an
individual
employee
attempts
to
negotiate
with
a
large
corporation
,
the
power
dynamics
are
overwhelmingly
skewed
.


However
,
when
all
workers
in
a
particular
sector
unite
,
they
create
a
formidable
force
that
can
compel
employers
to
listen
and
make
concessions
.



2
.


Awareness
and
Consciousness
:

Collective
action
often
involves
raising
awareness
about
the
issues
at
hand
.


It
encourages
individuals
to
develop
class
consciousness
,
a
foundational
concept
in
Marxian
economics
.


As
people
come
together
to
discuss
their
shared
struggles
and
experiences
,
they
become
more
conscious
of
the
structural
inequalities
in
society
.


This
heightened
awareness
can
galvanize
them
to
take
action
,
whether
through
protests
,
strikes
,
or
other
forms
of
collective
resistance
.



3
.


The
Role
of
Trade
Unions
:

Trade
unions
exemplify
the
power
of
collective
action
within
the
context
of
labor
.


They
act
as
intermediaries
between
workers
and
employers
,
advocating
for
better
wages
,
working
conditions
,
and
job
security
.


By
pooling
resources
and
leveraging
collective
bargaining
,
unions
empower
workers
to
challenge
the
status
quo
.


Consider
the
history
of
labor
movements
in
the
United
States
,
where
unions
played
a
pivotal
role
in
securing
workers
'

rights
and
influencing
labor
laws
.



4
.


Political
Mobilization
:

Beyond
economic
aspects
,
collective
action
can
also
translate
into
political
influence
.


When
individuals
come
together
with
shared
concerns
,
they
can
influence
public
policy
and
advocate
for
legislative
changes
that
benefit
the
working
class
.


Grassroots
movements
,
like
the
civil
Rights
movement
in
the
United
States
or
the
anti-apartheid
movement
in
South
Africa
,
demonstrated
the
transformative
power
of
collective
action
in
shaping
political
landscapes
.



5
.


Challenges
and
Counterarguments
:

It
is
important
to
acknowledge
that
collective
action
is
not
without
its
challenges
.


Some
argue
that
it
can
lead
to
groupthink
or
the
suppression
of
individual
voices
.


Critics
also
question
the
efficacy
of
collective
action
in
achieving
lasting
change
.


To
address
these
concerns
,
it
'
s
vital
to
strike
a
balance
between
collective
efforts
and
the
preservation
of
individual
agency
within
the
group
.



6
.


Digital
Era
Empowerment
:

In
the
digital
age
,
collective
action
has
found
new
avenues
for
expression
and
empowerment
.


social
media
platforms
have
become
catalysts
for
organizing
protests
,
spreading
awareness
,
and
amplifying
the
voices
of
marginalized
groups
.


Movements
like
#BlackLivesMatter
and
#MeToo
have
harnessed
the
power
of
online
collective
action
to
shed
light
on
injustices
and
demand
change
.



Collective
action
,
deeply
rooted
in
the
principles
of
solidarity
and
unity
,
stands
as
a
linchpin
in
the
quest
to
empower
the
proletariat
within
Marxian
economics
.


It
empowers
individuals
to
transcend
their
isolated
struggles
,
fosters
class
consciousness
,
and
amplifies
their
influence
in
economic
,
political
,
and
social
spheres
.


While
not
without
its
challenges
,
the
potential
for
transformative
change
through
collective
action
remains
a
powerful
force
in
shaping
a
more
equitable
and
just
society
.



-

-

-

-

-


Collective
Action
and
the
Path
to
Empowerment
-
Class
consciousness
:
Empowering
the
Proletariat
in
Marxian
Economics

------------------------------------------------------------------------

25
.

The
Impact
of
Wage
Labor
on
Society[Original
Blog]

Impact
of
the
wage

Wage
Labor

Wage
labor
has
been
a
crucial
component
of
the
labor
theory
of
value
and
has
greatly
impacted
society
as
a
whole
.


Some
view
wage
labor
as
a
necessary
aspect
of
modern
capitalism
,
while
others
argue
that
it
is
exploitative
and
perpetuates
economic
inequality
.


Regardless
of
one
'
s
perspective
,
it
is
clear
that
wage
labor
has
had
far-reaching
effects
on
various
aspects
of
society
,
including
the
economy
,
politics
,
and
social
relations
.



1
.


Economic
Impact
:
Wage
labor
has
played
a
significant
role
in
shaping
the
modern
economy
.


It
has
allowed
for
the
production
of
goods
and
services
on
a
large
scale
,
leading
to
increased
efficiency
and
productivity
.


However
,
wage
labor
can
also
contribute
to
economic
inequality
,
as
low-wage
workers
often
struggle
to
make
ends
meet
,
while
those
at
the
top
of
the
income
ladder
reap
the
benefits
of
their
labor
.


This
has
led
to
debates
about
the
minimum
wage
,
living
wage
,
and
the
need
for
greater
income
redistribution
.



2
.


Political
Impact
:
The
rise
of
wage
labor
has
also
had
important
political
implications
.


It
has
led
to
the
emergence
of
labor
unions
and
other
worker
advocacy
groups
,
which
have
fought
for
better
working
conditions
,
higher
wages
,
and
greater
workers
'

rights
.


However
,
wage
labor
has
also
been
used
as
a
tool
for
political
control
,
as
employers
can
use
the
threat
of
unemployment
to
keep
workers
in
line
and
prevent
them
from
organizing
.



3
.


Social
Impact
:
Wage
labor
has
also
had
a
profound
impact
on
social
relations
.


It
has
created
a
division
between
those
who
own
the
means
of
production
and
those
who
sell
their
labor
.


This
has
led
to
the
development
of
class
consciousness
,
as
workers
come
to
realize
their
shared
interests
and
common
struggles
.


At
the
same
time
,
wage
labor
can
also
create
social
divisions
within
the
working
class
,
as
workers
compete
with
one
another
for
jobs
and
wages
.



Overall
,
the
impact
of
wage
labor
on
society
is
complex
and
multifaceted
.


While
it
has
undoubtedly
played
a
crucial
role
in
the
development
of
modern
capitalism
,
it
has
also
led
to
economic
inequality
,
political
control
,
and
social
divisions
.


As
we
continue
to
grapple
with
these
issues
,
it
is
important
to
consider
the
broader
implications
of
wage
labor
and
to
work
towards
a
more
just
and
equitable
society
.



-

-

-

-

-


The
Impact
of
Wage
Labor
on
Society
-
Wage
Labor
:
A
Crucial
Component
of
Labor
Theory
of
Value

,

About
Us

FasterCapital
is
a
global
venture
builder
and
online
incubator
dedicated
to
co-funding
and
co-founding
innovative
startups
.


Established
in
2014
,
we
are
now
#1
venture
builder
in
terms
of
number
of
startups
that
we
have
helped
,
money
invested
and
money
raised
.



We
have
supported
over
734
startups
in
raising
more
than
$2
.

2
billion
,
while
directly
investing
over
$696
million
in
288
companies
.


Our
comprehensive
support
system
includes
a
worldwide
network
of
mentors
,
investors
,
and
strategic
partners
,
allowing
us
to
transform
ideas
into
scalable
,
market-ready
businesses
.



FasterCapital
operates
as
FasterCapital
LLC-FZ
,
a
duly
registered
entity
in
Dubai
.


Our
registration
number
is
2416362
.

[]

Key
Terms

Freedom
of
conscience
(section
2(a))
,
The
Charter

Freedom
of
Conscience

July
4
,
2019

[image_pdf]

[image_print]

PrintDownload
PDF

Freedom
of
conscience
is
one
of
the
fundamental
freedoms
protected
by
section
2
of
the Canadian
Charter
of
Rights
and
Freedoms
.

[1]

What
is
the
legal
impact
of
this
freedom
?



Ultimately
,
the
freedom
of
conscience
constitutionally
recognizes
“the
centrality
of
individual
conscience
and
the
inappropriateness
of
governmental
intervention
…
to
constrain
its
manifestation
.

”[2] In
fact
,
the
Supreme
Court
has
ruled
that
“an
emphasis
on
individual
conscience
and
individual
judgment
…
lies
at
the
heart
of
our
democratic
political
tradition
.


The
ability
of
each
citizen
to
make
free
and
informed
decisions
is
the
absolute
prerequisite
for
the
legitimacy
,
acceptability
,
and
efficacy
of
our
system
of
self‑government
.

”[3]

What
is
legally
protected
from
government
interference
?



The
only
Supreme
Court
case
considering
the
freedom
of
conscience
directly
is R
v
Morgentaler
.

[4]
This
1988
case
dealt
with
the
constitutionality
of
abortion
laws
.


Justice
Wilson
stated
:
“[t]he
decision
whether
or
not
to
terminate
a
pregnancy
is
essentially
a
moral
decision
and
…
the
conscience
of
the
individual
must
be
paramount
.

”[5] She
also
held
that
the
freedoms
guaranteed
by
section
2(a)
“should
be
broadly
construed
to
extend
to
conscientiously-held
beliefs
whether
grounded
in
religion
or
in
a
secular
morality
.

”[6] However
,
since
Justice
Wilson
opposed
the
majority
decision
of
the
Court
,
her
judgment
is
not
considered
a
settled
statement
of
the
law
.



Without
guidance
from
the
Supreme
Court
,
lower
courts
have
had
to
figure
out
on
their
own
what
the
freedom
of
conscience
protects
.


From
the
limited
jurisprudence
that
exists
,
we
know
“[t]he
guarantee
of
freedom
of
conscience
…
is
directed
at
an
individual
'
s
overarching
…
normative
value
system
.

”[7] If
a
person’s
actions
are
not
motivated
by
a
“comprehensive
value
system”
(in
a
secular
context)
,
 then
they
are
not
protected
by
section
2(a)
.

[8] This
can
be
quite
limiting
:
when
people
have
argued
that
their
freedom
of
conscience
was
violated
by
mandatory
seatbelt
laws
for
example
,
their
arguments
failed
because
their
objections
were
not
supported
by
a
comprehensive
value
system
.



‘Insubstantial’
infringements
upon
a
person’s
conscience
are
also
outside
of
the
scope
of
the
guarantee
.

[9] This
is
a
limitation
that
all
the
fundamental
freedoms
share
:
the freedom
of
religion for
instance
does
not
extend
to
protect
against
‘trivial’
infringements
upon
a
person’s
religious
practice
.

[10]

One
of
the
few
lower
court
decisions
solely
considering
the
freedom
of
conscience
,
rather
than
conscience
and
religion
together
,
was Maurice
v
Canada
(Attorney
General)
.

[11]
Mr
.


Maurice
wanted
to
receive
vegetarian
meals
in
prison
.


Originally
,
he
was
provided
with
these
meals
in
recognition
of
his freedom
of
religion
.


However
,
when
he
renounced
his
religious
beliefs
,
the
prison
stopped
providing
vegetarian
meals
.


He
successfully
claimed
that
,
since
he
remained
vegetarian
for
conscientious
reasons
,
this
was
a
violation
of
his
freedom
of
conscience
.

[12] The
Federal
Court
agreed
,
declaring
that
the
“Charter …
entitle[s]
the
Applicant
to
a
vegetarian
diet
.

”[13]

The
freedom
of
conscience
garnered
some
attention
in
2015
when
the
Supreme
Court
decided Carter
v
Canada
(Attorney
General)
.


In
that
case
,
a
number
of
interveners
claimed
that
providing
access
to
physician-assisted
dying
would
infringe
the
freedom
of
conscience
of
medical
professionals
.

[14] This
argument
went
beyond
the
scope
of
what
needed
to
be
decided
in
that
case
.


However
the
Court
noted
that
physician-assisted
dying
was
indeed
a
“matter
of
conscience”
and
that
at
some
point
“the Charter
rights
of
patients
and
physicians
will
need
to
be
reconciled
.

”[15]

What
are
the
limitations
on
the
freedom
of
conscience
?



While
the
freedom
of
conscience
is
a
fundamental
freedom
,
it
is
not
absolute
.


As
with
all
other
rights
and
freedoms
in
the Charter
,
if
a
breach
of
this
freedom
is
found
by
a
court
,
the
government
can
argue
that
its
laws
are
reasonable
and
justifiable
under section
1 of
the Charter
.

[16]

------------------------------------------------------------------------

[1] Canadian
Charter
of
Rights
and
Freedoms
,
s
2
,
Part
1
of
the Constitution
Act
,
1982
,
being
Schedule
B
to
the Canada
Act 1982 (UK)
,
1982
,
c
11
.



[2] R
v
Big
M
Drug
Mart
,
[1985]
1
SCR
295
at
346
,
18
DLR
(4th)
321
.



[3] Ibid
.



[4] R
v
Morgentaler
,
[1988]
1
SCR
30
,
44
DLR
(4th)
385
.



[5] Ibid at
175–76
.



[6] Ibid at
179
.



[7] R
v
Locke
,
2004
ABPC
152
at
para
24
.



[8] Ibid at
para
25
.



[9] R
v
Warman
,
2001
BCSC
1771
(The Warman ruling
considered
section
7
of
the Charter
of
Rights
and
Freedoms
.

 However
,
the
reasoning
was
adopted
in
the
section
2
context
by R
v
Dubbin
,
2009
BCPC
164)
.



[10] Note
that
the
freedom
of
expression
has
a
similar
threshold
:
for
example
,
see Police
Services
Union
,
Port
Moody
,
District
43
v
Port
Moody
Police
Board
,
(1991)
78
DLR
(4th)
79
at
88–89
;
54
BCLR
(2d)
2
(BCCA)
:
“These
types
of
cases
may
be
cases
of
expression
but
in
my
opinion
they
are
not
cases
of
constitutionally
protected
freedom
of
expression
.


They
are
too
trivial
.

”

[11] 210
DLR
(4th)
186
,
90
CRR
(2d)
240
.



[12] Ibid at
para
15
.



[13] Ibid
.

SCC
5
(Factum
of

Interveners
Catholic
Civil

,

and

Project
at
para
33)
;

also
2015
SCC
5
(Factum
of
the
Intervener
the
Canadian
Medical
Association)
(The
Canadian

Association
did
not
refer
to
section
2(a)
of
the Charter
of
Rights
and
Freedoms
, but
did
state
the
importance
of
physicians
being
able
to
follow

conscience
.

.

, supra note
1
,

1
.

of
Privacy
–
Personal
information
provided
is
collected
in
accordance
with
Section
33(c)
of
the
Alberta
Freedom
of
Information
and
Protection
of
Privacy
Act
(the
FOIP
Act)
and
will
be
protected
under
Part
2
of
that
Act
.


It will
be
used
for
the
purpose
of
managing
CCS’
email
subscription
lists
.


Should
you
require
further
information
about
collection
,

and

of

,

,

Free
Ebook
:
Which
Cosmetics
Use
Fetal
Cells
?



What
is
the
Role
of
Conscience
in
Moral
Decision-Making
?



Brian
Clowes
,
PhD|October
15
,
2021|No
Comments

[Print] Print

The
Modern
Misunderstanding
of
Conscience

The
Catholic
Church
teaches
that
the
conscience
is
a
natural
facility
of
our
reason
that
directs
us
to
do
good
and
avoid
evil
;
that
makes
judgments
about
the
good
and
evil
of
particular
acts
;
and
that
bears
witness
after
the
fact
to
the
good
or
evil
that
we
have
done
,
such
as
what
we
call
“having
a
guilty
conscience
.

”¹

A
fundamental
misunderstanding
of
the
role
of
the
human
conscience
lies
at
the
root
of
many
of
the
problems
in
the
Catholic
Church
today
.


Very
few
Catholics
even
know
what
that
role
actually
is
.


When
pressed
,
many
will
say
something
along
the
lines
of
“If
my
conscience
tells
me
that
a
particular
action
is
all
right
,
I
can
do
it
.

”

This
is
just
another
way
of
saying
“If
it
feels
good
,
do
it
.

”
If
an
improperly-formed
conscience
leads
a
person
to
accept
something
as
right
and
good
based
simply
on
his
or
her
uninformed
opinions
and
feelings
,
that
person
will
fall
into
grave
errors
for
which
there
is
no
good
excuse
before
God
:


When
Gentiles
who
have
not
the
law
do
by
nature
what
the
law
requires
,

they
are
a
law
to
themselves
,
even
though
they
do
not
have
the
law
.



They
show
that
what
the
law
requires
is
written
on
their
hearts
,
while

their
conscience
also
bears
witness
and
their
conflicting
thoughts

accuse
or
perhaps
excuse
them
on
that
day
when
,
according
to
my

gospel
,
God
judges
the
secrets
of
men
by
Christ
Jesus
.


(Romans

2
:14-15)

Many
Catholics
erroneously
believe
that
the
conscience
is
a
teacher
,
not
a
pupil
;
that
it
is
the
source
of
morality
.


This
is
not
the
teaching
of
the
Catholic
Church
.


According
to
the
Church
,
the
conscience
is
a
witness
to
the
moral
law
authored
by
God
.


Each
Catholic
is
required
to
obey
that
moral
law
in
all
things
.


The
conscience
,
if
properly
formed
,
calls
him
to
obey
that
moral
law
and
helps
him
to
understand
how
to
apply
it
in
particular
cases
.



This
is
why
the
cultivation
of
the
cardinal
virtue
of
prudence
is
essential
.


As
the
Catechism
teaches
,
“Man
strives
to
interpret
the
data
of
experience
and
the
signs
of
the
times
assisted
by
the
virtue
of
prudence
,
by
the
advice
of
competent
people
,
and
by
the
help
of
the
Holy
Spirit
and
his
gifts”
(¶1788)
.



[statue
of
man
thinking][statue
of
man
thinking]

 

Result
:
A
Deformed
Belief
System

The
belief
that
the
conscience
is
a
moral
authority
in
its
own
right
has
resulted
in
Catholics
supporting
and
promoting
many
intrinsic
evils
,
including
contraception
,
sterilization
,
abortion
,
homosexual
activity
,
pornography
and
euthanasia
.



Many
organizations
vigorously
promote
this
false
understanding
of
the
human
conscience
in
order
to
gain
more
support
from
Catholic
laity
.


One
of
these
groups
is
“Catholics”
for
Choice
(CFC)
,
whose
mission
consists
of
attempting
to
convince
people
that
they
can
be
pro-abortion
and
still
be
“good
Catholics
.

”
In
its
quarterly
magazine
,
ironically
entitled
Conscience
,
CFC
attempts
to
legitimize
the
obvious
paradox
that
“Church
law
affirms
both
the
right
and
the
responsibility
of
a
Catholic
to
follow
his
or
her
conscience
,
even
when
it
conflicts
with
church
teaching”²
(emphasis
added)
.



CFC
also
alleges
:


The
Catholic
Church
officially
teaches
that
the
conscience
of
an

individual
is
supreme
.


If
you
carefully
examine
your
conscience
and

then
decide
that
an
abortion
is
the
most
moral
act
you
can
do
at
this

time
,
you
are
not
committing
a
sin
.


Therefore
,
you
are
not

excommunicated
.


Nor
need
you
tell
it
in
confession
,
since
,
in
your

case
,
abortion
is
not
a
sin
.

³

It
is
easy
to
demonstrate
that
CFC
does
not
really
believe
this
principle
itself
.


For
example
,
would
it
concede
that
it
was
legitimate
for
someone
to
“carefully
examine
their
conscience”
and
then
decide
that
torching
an
abortion
clinic
in
the
middle
of
the
night
was
“the
most
moral
act
they
could
do
at
this
time
?

”

Obviously
not
.



This
is
a
fundamental
error
,
and
are
many
examples
of
how
it
naturally
carries
over
into
other
moral
issues
.


Teresa
Kelly
,
a
member
of
Toronto’s
Catholic
school
board
,
recently
said
that
being
part
of
a
gay-straight
alliance
whose
purpose
is
to
disseminate
homophile
propaganda
in
the
schools
is
“the
embodiment
of
a
perfectly-formed
Catholic
conscience
.

”
She
dismissed
her
critics
,
who
quoted
actual
Church
teachings
on
homosexuality
,
as
“archaic
.

”⁴

[catholic
confessional][catholic
confessional]

 

Personal
Judgement
vs
.


Objective
Standards

How
does
conscience
relate
to
morality
?



In
order
for
a
person’s
conscience
to
be
conditioned
to
accept
evil
,
it
must
first
decisively
turn
away
from
God’s
teachings
and
decide
that
it
can
determine
for
itself
what
is
right
and
wrong
,
ignoring
all
external
and
objective
standards
if
necessary
in
order
to
reach
the
desired
conclusion
.



This
means
that
dissenters
must
justify
their
claims
by
assuming
that
there
is
no
fixed
morality
that
is
binding
on
all
persons
.


The
only
source
of
morality
is
the
conscience
of
each
individual
.


One
phrase
that
is
coming
into
common
usage
among
the
self-appointed
elite
is
“This
is
my
truth
.

”

However
,
the
intrinsic
flaw
with
that
understanding
is
the
fact
that
every
human
being
is
naturally
attuned
to
their
own
subjective
view
of
the
world
.


This
subjective
view
exists
in
order
to
promote
the
highest
good
of
the
individual
.


However
,
if
that
view
is
not
held
to
an
objective
standard
,
it
is
easy
for
the
individual
to
consider
not
what
is
morally
good
(i
.

e
.


,
virtuous)
but
rather
what
is
personally
good
(i
.

e
.


,
convenient)
.



This
type
of
thinking
leads
many
to
justify
actions
that
no
moral
law
would
permit
.



[natural
law
gives
moral
principles
to
conscience
,
which
then
makes
decisions][natural
law
gives
moral
principles
to
conscience
,
which
then
makes
decisions]

 

Catholics
and
Church
Teaching

It
is
one
thing
for
a
person
to
say
“I
disagree
with
the
Church’s
teaching
on
abortion
.

”
It
is
another
thing
entirely
to
say
“The
Church
teaches
that
abortion
is
permissible
,
so
long
as
my
conscience
allows
it
.

”
This
statement
is
false
,
and
can
only
be
uttered
by
one
who
is
grossly
ignorant
of
Church
teaching
or
who
deliberately
lies
about
such
teaching
.



Ignorance
is
certainly
no
excuse
for
committing
sin
because
every
Catholic
has
the
duty
to
know
what
is
evil
and
what
is
not
,
and
,
further
,
they
should
know
why
certain
activities
are
evil
.


Secular
courts
enforce
the
general
rule
that
“ignorance
of
the
law
is
no
excuse
,”
and
everyone
accepts
this
principle
;
why
should
it
be
any
different
for
the
eternal
law
?



A
person
is
culpable
for
the
evil
he
commits
when
he
“takes
little
trouble
to
find
out
what
is
true
and
good
,
or
when
conscience
is
by
degrees
almost
blinded
through
the
habit
of
committing
sin
.

”⁵

[ignorance][ignorance]

 

The
Formation
of
the
Conscience

The
conscience
is
a
precious
gift
and
it
must
be
cared
for
by
forming
it
with
prayer
and
education
for
the
duration
of
our
lives
.



The
Catechism
states
,
“The
education
of
conscience
is
indispensable
for
human
beings
who
are
subjected
to
negative
influences
and
tempted
by
sin
to
prefer
their
own
judgment
and
to
reject
authoritative
teachings”
(¶1783)
.



A
dead
giveaway
that
a
person’s
conscience
is
improperly
formed
is
when
he
or
she
says
something
like
“I
respect
the
teachings
of
the
Church
,
but
I
follow
my
own
conscience
in
matters
of
sexual
morality
.

”
Nancy
Pelosi
gave
us
a
typical
example
of
this
deception
when
she
claimed
that
she
was
a
“practicing
and
respectful
Catholic”
but
,
regarding
the
Church’s
teachings
on
abortion
,
“My
faith
isn’t
about
what
their
position
is
.

”⁶

This
means
that
the
person’s
conscience
has
become
disconnected
from
the
truth
.


This
has
several
root
causes
(Catechism
,
¶1792)
:

-
“Ignorance
of
Christ
and
His
Gospel
,
-
Bad
example
given
by
others
,
-
Enslavement
to
one’s
passions
,
-
Assertion
of
a
mistaken
notion
of
autonomy
of
conscience
,
-
Rejection
of
the
Church’s
authority
and
her
teaching
,
-
Lack
of
conversion
and
of
charity
.

”

By
contrast
,
a
properly‑formed
Catholic
conscience
has
been
rigorously
educated
,
is
fully
aware
of
the
intrinsically
evil
nature
of
abortion
and
other
evils
,
and
is
led
by
this
knowledge
to
vigorously
oppose
them
.



Failure
to
act
is
not
a
viable
option
.



It
is
true
that
Catholics
must
follow
their
consciences
,
but
their
consciences
must
be
formed
by
the
Word
of
God
,
which
is
authentically
interpreted
and
taught
by
the
Magisterium
of
the
Catholic
Church
,
to
which
Christ
entrusted
His
authority
to
teach
in
His
Name
.


The
conscience
must
be
continuously
schooled
to
recognize
,
not
to
determine
,
what
is
and
is
not
moral
activity
.



As
the
Catechism
teaches
,
“Objective
rules
of
morality
express
the
rational
order
of
good
and
evil
,
attested
to
by
conscience
.

…
It
is
by
the
judgment
of
conscience
that
man
perceives
and
recognizes
the
prescriptions
of
the
divine
law”
(¶1751
,
1778)
.



 

[decision
making
;
conscience][decision
making
;
conscience]

Conscience
and
Vatican
II

Some
appeal
to
an
ill‑defined
“Spirit
of
Vatican
II”
to
support
their
concept
of
the
human
conscience
.


They
use
vague
terms
such
as
“renewal
,”
“reinvigoration”
and
“rejuvenation”
of
the
Church
,
while
consciously
misrepresenting
what
the
documents
of
the
Council
actually
say
.


They
often
quote
the
Vatican
II
document
Dignitatis
Humanae
(“Declaration
on
Religious
Freedom”)
in
support
of
their
contention
that
people
should
be
able
to
do
anything
their
uneducated
consciences
do
not
object
to
.

⁷

However
,
this
is
obviously
not
what
the
Fathers
of
Vatican
II
taught
.


They
instead
laid
out
very
clearly
the
multiple
dangers
inherent
in
this
line
of
thinking
.


In
Gaudium
et
Spes
,
they
wrote
,
“Conscience
frequently
errs
from
invincible
ignorance
without
losing
its
dignity
.


The
same
cannot
be
said
for
a
man
who
cares
but
little
for
truth
and
goodness
,
or
for
a
conscience
which
by
degrees
grows
practically
sightless
as
a
result
of
habitual
sin”
(¶16‑17)
.


Furthermore
,
the
document
notes
that
“not
a
few
can
be
found
who
seem
inclined
to
use
the
name
of
freedom
as
the
pretext
for
refusing
to
submit
to
authority
and
for
making
light
of
the
duty
of
obedience
.

”⁸

The
document
continues
by
confirming
an
essential
principle
:
That
the
conscience
must
submit
itself
to
the
authority
of
the
Church
:


In
forming
their
consciences
,
the
Christian
faithful
must
give
careful

attention
to
the
sacred
and
certain
teaching
of
the
Church
.


For
the

Catholic
Church
is
by
the
will
of
Christ
the
teacher
of
truth
.


Her

charge
is
to
announce
and
teach
authentically
that
truth
which
is

Christ
,
and
at
the
same
time
with
her
authority
to
declare
and
confirm

the
principles
of
the
moral
order
which
derive
from
human
nature

itself
.


(¶14)

Conscience
does
have
a
very
particular
and
necessary
role
given
by
God
.


As
defined
in
Romans
2
:12‑16
and
Jeremiah
31
:33
,
God
imprints
the
natural
law
on
the
heart
and
soul
of
man
,
and
this
leads
him
to
know
whether
or
not
an
act
is
moral
or
evil
.

⁹
This
means
that
the
“natural
law”
is
man’s
instinctual
knowledge
of
what
is
right
and
what
is
wrong
―
his
“conscience
.

”
However
,
the
conscience
must
work
with
the
teachings
of
the
Church
,
never
against
it
.



 

Conscientious
Objection

The
Church
,
as
demonstrated
in
a
particularly
vivid
manner
by
Her
martyrs
,
has
always
held
that
a
person’s
properly-formed
conscience
may
never
be
violated
.


Countless
men
,
women
and
even
children
have
courageously
stated
,
“You
may
kill
me
,
but
you
will
never
force
me
to
violate
my
conscience
.

”

This
principle
has
more
recently
been
recognized
by
secular
authorities
.


The
United
Nations
,
in
both
its
1948
Universal
Declaration
of
Human
Rights
and
its
1966
International
Covenant
on
Civil
and
Political
Rights
,
states
that
“everyone
has
the
right
to
freedom
of
thought
,
conscience
and
religion
.

”

When
society
fails
to
acknowledge
conscience
as
a
human
right
and
does
not
provide
protections
for
individuals
to
follow
their
own
consciences
,
grave
conflicts
inevitably
result
.


Either
people
will
heroically
obey
their
consciences
whatever
the
cost
,
or
they
will
lose
their
moral
integrity
with
all
the
devastating
effects
that
flow
from
this
on
society
at
large
.



There
are
thousands
of
incidents
on
record
where
conscientious
objectors
are
severely
punished
,
particularly
in
the
health
care
profession
.


Many
have
been
fined
,
dismissed
from
their
jobs
,
and
even
in
some
cases
jailed
for
refusing
to
participate
in
such
intrinsic
evils
such
as
dispensing
contraceptives
and
abortifacients
and
refusing
to
participate
in
such
fundamental
violations
of
human
dignity
as
abortion
,
euthanasia
,
and
so-called
“sex-changed”
surgeries
.



 

Conclusion

Tragically
,
many
Catholics
possess
a
fatally
flawed
concept
of
conscience
,
denying
the
need
for
formation
in
the
truth
,
and
treating
mere
desire
as
an
absolute
.


Conscience
is
indeed
a
decision-maker
,
but
it
must
be
freely
submitted
to
the
law
of
God
,
to
which
it
is
a
witness
,
not
an
arbiter
.



The
error
lies
not
in
affirming
the
freedom
of
conscience
to
decide
,
but
in
misinterpreting
the
nature
of
such
freedom
.


Freedom
of
conscience
must
be
at
the
service
of
moral
truth
but
can
never
be
its
determinant
.



 

Endnotes
:

of

Catholic
Church
,

;

:

for

Faith”
at
http
://beginningcatholic
.

com/conscience
.

Steve
Askin
.

the
Right
.

of

,

and

;

and

Thought
:
The
Little‑Known
History
.

”

,
Autumn
1996
,

2
to
5
.

“Catholics”
for

.

Are

:

for

,

.

.

,

reprint
.

Patrick
B
.


Craine
.

Catholic

Gay
Club
is

of

Catholic
Conscience
.

’”
LifeSite
Daily
News
,

27
,
2013
.

of

,
¶1791
;
Vatican
II
,
Gaudium
et
Spes
[“On
the
Church
in
the
Modern
World”]
,
¶16
.



[6]
John
Jalsevac
.


“Pelosi
Laughs
Off
Priest’s
Letter
Challenging
Abortion
Views
,
Says
He
Was
‘Acting
Hysterically
.

’”
LifeSite
Daily
News
,
June
25
,
2013
.



[7]
As
one
example
,
Frances
Kissling
says
,
“In
its
approach
to
the
[abortion]
issue
,
the
organization
[“Catholics”
for
Choice]
relied
on
the
Declaration
on
Religious
Freedom
,
the
Second
Vatican
Council’s
endorsement
of
the
separation
of
church
and
state
,
pluralism
,
and
the
primacy
of
conscience”
[Frances
Kissling
,
in
“CFFC
Notebook
:
A
Mouse
that
Roars
Turns
20
.

”
Conscience
,
Spring/Summer
1993
,
page
54]
.



[8]
Dignitatis
Humanae
,
¶8
.


Father
John
Courtney
Murray
,
S
.

J
.


,
principal
author
of
this
document
,
anticipated
this
kind
of
dishonesty
.


He
stated
in
a
footnote
to
the
Abbott‑Gallagher
edition
of
the
Council
texts
:


The
Declaration
does
not
base
the
right
to
the
free
exercise
of

religion
on
“freedom
of
conscience
.

”
Nowhere
does
this
phrase
occur
.



And
the
Declaration
nowhere
lends
its
authority
to
the
theory
for

which
the
phrase
frequently
stands
,
namely
,
that
I
have
the
right
to

do
what
my
conscience
tells
me
to
do
,
simply
because
my
conscience

tells
me
to
do
it
.


This
is
a
perilous
theory
.


Its
particular
peril
is

subjectivism
―
the
notion
that
,
in
the
end
,
it
is
my
conscience
,
and

not
the
objective
truth
,
which
determines
what
is
right
and
wrong
,

true
or
false
.



Father
John
Courtney
Murray
,
S
.

J
.


,
principal
author
of
Vatican
II’s
Declaration
on
Religious
Freedom
,
quoted
in
Russell
Shaw
.


“Answers
.

”
National
Catholic
Register
,
September
13
,
1992
,
page
4
.



[9]
The
Bible
contains
many
references
to
the
human
conscience
.


It
describes
the
fate
of
someone
who
does
not
guard
or
“keep”
his
conscience
(Hebrews
9
:14
and
1
Peter
3
:16)
,
and
who
allows
his
conscience
to
become
“seared”
(1
Timothy
4
:2)
.


The
Bible
also
speaks
of
a
“weak
conscience”
(1
Corinthians
8
:7)
,
a
“wounded
conscience”
(1
Corinthians
8
:12)
,
a
“good”
and
“perfect”
conscience
(Hebrews
9
:9
and
13
:18
;
1
Peter
3
:21
;
and
1
Timothy
1
:5
,19)
;
a
“clear”
or
blameless
conscience
(Acts
24
:16
and
1
Timothy
3
:9)
,
and
a
conscience
that
is
“evil”
or
defiled
(Titus
1
:15)
.

Brian

Dr
.


Brian
Clowes
has

HLI’s
director
of
research
since
1995
and
is
one
of
the
most
accomplished
and
respected
intellectuals
in
the
international
pro-life
movement
.


Best
known
as
author
of
the
most
exhaustive
pro-life
informational
resource
volume
The
Facts
of
Life
,
and
for
his
Pro-Life
Basic
Training
Course
,
Brian
is
the
author
of
nine
books
and
over
500
scholarly
and
popular
articles
,
and
has
traveled
to
70
countries
on
six
continents
as
a
pro-life
speaker
,
educator
and
trainer
.

.

.

[]

Examining
the
Role
of
Conscience
in
Making
Moral
Decisions

 [Examining
the
Role
of
Conscience
in
Making
Moral
Decisions]

[]

[]

Q
:
I
disagree
with
some
of
the
teachings
of
the
Catholic
Church
.


I
was
once
told
that
I
don’t
have
to
follow
all
of
the
church’s
teachings
if
they
violate
my
conscience
.


But
still
,
I’m
not
sure
that’s
right
.



A
:
First
,
I
want
to
commend
you
for
asking
this
question
.


The
fact
that
you
were
moved
to
ask
demonstrates
two
things
:
that
God’s
grace
can
be
operative
in
every
person
who
is
open
to
him
,
and
secondly
that
you
are
sincere
in
your
desire
to
do
God’s
will
.



I
have
run
into
a
number
of
people
in
a
similar
predicament
as
you
.


They
asked
someone
who
ought
to
be
able
to
give
some
guidance
on
what
was
a
difficult
moral
question
.


In
response
,
they
seemed
to
get
an
answer
that
indicated
that
,
in
the
end
,
they
had
to
just
“follow
their
conscience
.

”

I
can
understand
this
.


In
the
course
of
my
life
as
a
priest
,
I
have
(like
all
of
my
brother
priests)
been
asked
to
weigh
in
on
life
situations
in
which
there
were
no
easy
or
obvious
answers
.


At
times
,
after
going
through
all
of
the
tools
and
resources
the
church
offers
for
right
decision-making
,
the
right
way
to
go
remained
foggy
and
difficult
.




“When
he
listens
to
his
conscience
,
the
prudent
man
can
hear
God

speaking”
—CCC
1777

In
addition
,
the
Catechism
of
the
Catholic
Church
teaches
:
“When
he
listens
to
his
conscience
,
the
prudent
man
can
hear
God
speaking”
(CCC
1777)
.


Because
of
this
line
and
others
that
highlight
the
importance
of
conscience
,
it
is
tempting
to
take
the
default
position
of
“whatever
you
feel
is
right
,
just
do
that
.

”

I
am
not
denying
this
.


After
all
,
this
is
clearly
part
of
the
catechism
.


(I’m
not
about
to
go
toe-to-toe
with
the
catechism
and
think
that
I
can
win
!


I’m
not
that
smart
.

)
But
it
misses
crucial
pieces
of
information
.



First
,
while
it
is
essential
that
we
are
sincere
in
the
decisions
we
make
,
we
don’t
only
have
an
obligation
to
ourselves
.


This
is
something
that
we
have
lost
in
our
culture
.



We
think
that
“to
thine
own
self
be
true”
is
the
highest
commandment
.


It
isn’t
.


While
it
is
good
to
be
truthful
and
interiorly
at
peace
,
we
also
must
be
true
to
others
.


It’s
even
more
essential
that
we
are
true
to
God
.


We
may
have
an
obligation
to
strive
for
authenticity
,
but
we
also
have
an
obligation
to
obey
God
.


I
am
not
the
only
one
to
whom
I
must
be
true
.



Second
,
the
church’s
teaching
on
conscience
presumes
knowledge
of
the
moral
law
.


This
means
that
those
who
are
exercising
conscience
know
that
there
is
a
real
right
and
a
real
wrong
.


Unfortunately
,
there
are
fewer
people
who
acknowledge
this
reality
.


This
places
us
in
a
unique
place
in
human
history
.




We
may
have
an
obligation
to
strive
for
authenticity
,
but
we
also
have

an
obligation
to
obey
God
.



A
recent
study
reported
that
only
8
percent
of
American
teenagers
believe
in
a
real
right
and
a
real
wrong
.


This
ignorance
is
unprecedented
.


Notre
Dame
sociologist
Christian
Smith
recently
concluded
a
nationwide
study
on
the
moral
life
of
18-
to
29-year-olds
.


His
conclusion
was
that
this
age
group
,
generally
speaking
,
has
neither
the
vocabulary
nor
the
categories
to
make
moral
decisions
.


If
conscience
depends
on
principles
of
right
and
wrong
,
how
will
these
young
people
make
decisions
?


According
to
Smith
,
they
base
their
decisions
on
feelings
.



But
conscience
is
not
a
feeling
.


The
catechism
clearly
states
that
conscience
“formulates
its
judgments
according
to
reason
,
in
conformity
with
the
true
good
willed
by
the
wisdom
of
the
Creator”
(CCC
1783)
.


This
means
employing
one’s
mind
more
than
one’s
emotions
to
make
decisions
.


Conscience
is
not
merely
some
feeling
we
get
;
it
is
the
critical
application
of
truth
to
the
present
issue
.



Third
,
it
is
true
that
,
a
person
“must
not
be
forced
to
act
contrary
to
his
conscience
.


Nor
must
he
be
prevented
from
acting
according
to
his
conscience
,
especially
in
religious
matters”
(CCC
1782)
.


But
this
does
not
mean
doing
whatever
pleases
me
.



Let’s
take
a
potentially
explosive
issue
.


When
Pope
Paul
VI
reinforced
the
church’s
constant
teaching
against
artificial
birth
control
in
the
document
“Humanae
Vitae
,”
many
couples
were
encouraged
to
dismiss
this
teaching
if
it
“violated
their
conscience
.

”
Unfortunately
,
as
a
result
,
many
couples
were
obliquely
encouraged
to
invite
a
sinful
practice
into
their
sexual
relationship
.


Even
more
,
they
were
led
to
believe
that
they
could
dismiss
virtually
any
official
and
binding
church
teaching
if
they
disliked
it
.



Because
that
is
all
this
comes
down
to
.


The
church’s
teaching
on
contraception
does
not
“violate”
a
person’s
conscience
.


Unless
a
person
truly
believed
that
periodic
abstinence
in
marriage
was
an
evil
(which
is
all
that
is
being
asked
for
through
natural
family
planning)
,
then
there
is
no
conscience
issue
here
.


It
is
an
issue
of
a)
not
knowing
or
understanding
the
church’s
teaching
(which
could
be
remedied
by
asking
someone
who
knows)
,
b)
lacking
the
will
to
choose
the
good
(which
is
always
an
issue
for
every
person
striving
to
live
virtuously
,
but
not
a
good
reason
to
choose
sin
over
virtue)
,
or
c)
a
matter
of
personal
dislike
for
a
particular
teaching
or
the
church
in
general
.




Seek
to
do
his
will
above
absolutely
all
else
.


Even
in
very
difficult

circumstances
,
God
can
be
trusted
.



After
all
of
this
,
if
we
still
have
reasonable
doubt
regarding
what
to
do
,
we
ought
to
do
the
following
.


First
,
pray
.


Second
,
it
is
wise
to
examine
your
conscience
regularly
.


Third
,
choose
to
do
good
.


Fourth
,
seek
wise
and
holy
counsel
from
someone
who
is
not
only
educated
in
the
area
of
morality
but
who
personally
defers
to
the
wisdom
of
Christ
and
his
church
in
all
things
.


Lastly
,
trust
God
.


He
comes
to
our
aid
in
times
of
weakness
and
confusion
.


Seek
to
do
his
will
above
absolutely
all
else
.


Even
in
very
difficult
circumstances
,
God
can
be
trusted
.



Examining
the
Role
of
Conscience
in
Making
Moral
Decisions2016-02-012018-09-25https
://bulldogcatholic

Ministries

of

Duluth
.


He
also
serves
as

of

of

Ministry
for
the
Diocese
of
Duluth
.


You
can
listen
to

.

homilies
in
iTunes
and
Spotify
.

Bio
,
